Americans are, apparently, tired of having every last shred of personal data over-collected, hyper monetized, then improperly secured by a rotating crop of ethics-optional corporations and lazy exe…

<h1 class="posttitle">

	
			84% Of Americans Want Tougher Online Privacy Laws, But Congress Is Too Corrupt To Follow Through
	
	
</h1>

				
<div class="details">

	
				<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/?s&topic=privacy">
					<img class="topic_icon" src="https://www.techdirt.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/02/privacy.jpg" />
				</a>

				
		<p>
			<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/?s&topic=privacy">
				Privacy			</a>
		</p>

		
</div>

				<h3>from the <i>this-is-why-we-can't-have-nice-things</i> dept</h3>
				
<div class="byline">

	<span class="pub_date">
		Wed, Aug 21st 2024 05:32am - 	</span>

	<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/user/kbode/" title="Posts by Karl Bode" class="author url fn" rel="author">Karl Bode</a>
</div>

				<p>Americans are, apparently, tired of having every last shred of personal data over-collected, hyper monetized, then improperly secured by a rotating crop of ethics-optional corporations and lazy executives.</p>
<p>A <a href="https://www.usnews.com/360-reviews/privacy/digital-privacy-concerns-habits-survey">new survey from U.S. News and World Report</a> took a look at prevailing U.S. consumer privacy beliefs, and found, among other things, that 84% of the public wants Congress to pass tougher privacy laws:</p>
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote is-layout-flow wp-block-quote-is-layout-flow">
<p><em>“In our survey, 84% of respondents said the federal government should implement stricter data privacy laws, and just 16% said it should not. Congress has been deadlocked for years on this question, although a bipartisan effort appeared to be making some headway in 2024.”</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>As is the norm for U.S. journalism, the outlet frames our failure to pass an internet privacy law over the last 30 years as something that <em>just kind of happened</em> without meaningful cause. The “question” of whether to have even baseline public privacy protections has been left unanswered due to some sort of <em>ambiguous externality</em>. Just blame that pesky, <em>ambiguous gridlock</em>. </p>
<p>In reality, Congress hasn’t passed a privacy law because it’s blisteringly, grotesquely corrupt. U.S. policymakers have decided, time and time and time again, that making gobs of money is more important than consumer welfare, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/02/15/wyden-data-broker-used-abortion-clinic-visitor-location-data-to-help-send-targeted-misinformation-to-vulnerable-women/">public safety</a>, market health, or even <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/03/11/once-more-with-feeling-banning-tiktok-doesnt-do-much-if-we-dont-regulate-data-brokers-and-pass-a-privacy-law/">national security</a> (see: our obsession with TikTok, while <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/03/11/once-more-with-feeling-banning-tiktok-doesnt-do-much-if-we-dont-regulate-data-brokers-and-pass-a-privacy-law/">ignoring the national security risks of unregulated data brokers</a>).</p>
<p>The federal government is also disincentivized from passing a nationwide privacy law for the internet era because they’ve found that buying consumer data from data brokers is a wonderful way to <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2023/03/16/fbi-latest-to-admit-to-bypassing-warrant-requirements-by-purchasing-location-info-from-data-brokers/">avoid having to get a traditional warrant</a>. </p>
<p>You could, on any random day, pluck any of a million mainstream news reports on consumer privacy from the newswire and not find a single one willing to make either of these causes clear to readers. Yes, getting everybody aligned on quality privacy legislation is difficult, but it’s not <em>30 straight years of inaction</em> difficult. At some point, this reckless disregard for public welfare is a feature, not a bug.</p>
<p>All of that said, it’s evident that the public isn’t great when it comes to personal responsibility. Most of the users surveyed didn’t engage in basic protective measures like two-factor authentication or reliable, encrypted password managers:</p>
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote is-layout-flow wp-block-quote-is-layout-flow">
<p><em>“42% use multi-factor authentication, seen by experts as a good way to protect online accounts, and just over half (53%) use security questions to verify their identity. Only one in six (17%) said they use a <a href="https://www.usnews.com/360-reviews/privacy/password-managers" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">password manager</a> app or software that creates hard-to-break passwords, and 27% said they used biometric authentication such as facial recognition or fingerprint.”</em></p>
</blockquote>
<p>In the absence of federal and state protection from reckless data monetization, consumers have to have their own backs, and it’s clear we’re not particularly good at that, either. </p>

				
<p class="filed">

	Filed Under: <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/consumers/" rel="tag">consumers</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/corruption/" rel="tag">corruption</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/law/" rel="tag">law</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/privacy/" rel="tag">privacy</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/security/" rel="tag">security</a>, <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/tag/survey/" rel="tag">survey</a>
	<br />

	
</p>

		<div id="comment-4001094" data-comment-date="20240821144949" class="comment by-user comment-author-sonicanatidae odd alt thread-even parent" data-depth="1">

						<article id="div-comment-4001094" class="comment-body">

				
				<header class="comment-meta">
					
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img alt='' src='https://www.techdirt.com/wp-content/themes/techdirt/assets/images/user-default.jpg' class='avatar avatar-120 photo' height='120' width='120' /><span class="fn">31Bob</span> <a href="https://www.techdirt.com/user/sonicanatidae/" rel="external nofollow" class="url">(profile)</a> <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/08/21/84-of-americans-want-tougher-online-privacy-laws-but-congress-is-too-corrupt-to-follow-through/#comment-4001094"><time datetime="2024-08-21T07:49:49-07:00">August 21, 2024 at 7:49 am</time></a>
					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

					<h1 class="comment-title">
											</h1>

				</header><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content entry-content">

					<p>“42% use multi-factor authentication, seen by experts as a good way to protect online accounts, and just over half (53%) use security questions to verify their identity. Only one in six (17%) said they use a password manager app or software that creates hard-to-break passwords, and 27% said they used biometric authentication such as facial recognition or fingerprint.”</p>
<p>Part of this is the patchwork hell of MFA. I currently have 5 AUTH APPs installed on my fucking work phone, because everyone has to “build a better mousetrap”.</p>
<p>Password managers get breached. Ask those fucking clowns at LastPass since PLEX is more important to them than your data.</p>
<p>Facial recognition is a reasonable approach for most. It’s developed enough that simple pictures, you sleeping, etc. usually don’t allow access. However, you cannot prevent cops from accessing your phone, if you use biometrics, because of overreach.</p>

				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

				<footer class="comment-footer-meta">

						<article id="div-comment-4001134" class="comment-body">

									<button class="thread-level"><span class="screen-reader-text">Threaded</span><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" viewBox="0 0 20 18"><use xlink:href="#icon-comments-inline" /></svg> [2]</button>
					
				<header class="comment-meta">
					
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img alt src="https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/dc83134f7e8feeb589293a9a2a83de20?d=identicon&s=240" class="avatar avatar-120" /><span class="fn">Anonymous Coward</span>  <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/08/21/84-of-americans-want-tougher-online-privacy-laws-but-congress-is-too-corrupt-to-follow-through/#comment-4001134"><time datetime="2024-08-21T09:17:01-07:00">August 21, 2024 at 9:17 am</time></a>
					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

					<h1 class="comment-title">
						Re: 					</h1>

				</header><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content entry-content">

					<p>– Lastpass has been either incompetent or a scam from the very beginning. NOBODY should use them, ever.</p>
<p>– Facial recognition is obsolete thanks to AI.</p>
<p>-MFA apps are garbage.</p>
<p>– One of the best ways to secure passwords, as it turns out, is to <i>write them down</i> and then stash them in places that attackers are unlikely to look — and unlikely to figure out even if they do.  Let me give you an example: my eBay password is 18 (very random) characters long.  It’s written on a bookmark (just the password, not the word “ebay”) and that bookmark is tucked inside one of several thousand books.</p>
<p>In order for an attacker to come up with it, they’d have to break into my house, figure out that I wrote the password down, and then figure out where that piece of paper is, and then figure out that it’s an ebay password and not something else.  (How do I use it?  I have it memorized, along with several hundred other similar passwords. The bookmark is just a backup.)</p>

				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

		<div id="comment-4001233" data-comment-date="20240821174542" class="comment odd alt thread-even parent" data-depth="1">

						<article id="div-comment-4001233" class="comment-body">

				
				<header class="comment-meta">
					
					<div class="comment-author vcard">
						<img alt src="https://www.gravatar.com/avatar/5a68e52f25122e9dd061852bcedf2e38?d=identicon&s=240" class="avatar avatar-120" /><span class="fn">Mick</span>  <span class="screen-reader-text says">says:</span>					</div><!-- .comment-author -->

					<div class="comment-metadata">
						<a href="https://www.techdirt.com/2024/08/21/84-of-americans-want-tougher-online-privacy-laws-but-congress-is-too-corrupt-to-follow-through/#comment-4001233"><time datetime="2024-08-21T10:45:42-07:00">August 21, 2024 at 10:45 am</time></a>
					</div><!-- .comment-metadata -->

					<h1 class="comment-title">
						In this case, it's not (just) corruption					</h1>

				</header><!-- .comment-meta -->

				<div class="comment-content entry-content">

					<p>It’s not about corruption; it’s about surveillance.</p>
<p>All the data that’s hoovered up and passed around by Big Tech, ISPs, credit card companies, and data brokers is bought and used by law enforcement and various 3-letter agencies as much as (or more than) anyone else.</p>
<p>If Congress were to start thinking about privacy laws, the largest lobbying efforts against it would come from inside the house: the NSA, FBI, CIA, and the DHS.  THAT’S why it will never happen. Stories like this one that ignore that part of the issue — which is the most important part of the issue — are not helpful.</p>
<p>Fixing the issue has to BEGIN with a discussion of the types of surveillance these agencies are permitted to do against US citizens, and THAT’S where the pressure needs to be put on Congress. Commentary like Bode’s is a gift to the Surveillance State.</p>

				</div><!-- .comment-content -->

readabilityObject.title: 84% Of Americans Want Tougher Online Privacy Laws, But Congress Is Too Corrupt To Follow Through
readabilityObject.content:
from the this-is-why-we-can't-have-nice-things dept

Americans are, apparently, tired of having every last shred of personal data over-collected, hyper monetized, then improperly secured by a rotating crop of ethics-optional corporations and lazy executives.

A new survey from U.S. News and World Report took a look at prevailing U.S. consumer privacy beliefs, and found, among other things, that 84% of the public wants Congress to pass tougher privacy laws:

“In our survey, 84% of respondents said the federal government should implement stricter data privacy laws, and just 16% said it should not. Congress has been deadlocked for years on this question, although a bipartisan effort appeared to be making some headway in 2024.”

As is the norm for U.S. journalism, the outlet frames our failure to pass an internet privacy law over the last 30 years as something that just kind of happened without meaningful cause. The “question” of whether to have even baseline public privacy protections has been left unanswered due to some sort of ambiguous externality. Just blame that pesky, ambiguous gridlock.

In reality, Congress hasn’t passed a privacy law because it’s blisteringly, grotesquely corrupt. U.S. policymakers have decided, time and time and time again, that making gobs of money is more important than consumer welfare, public safety, market health, or even national security (see: our obsession with TikTok, while ignoring the national security risks of unregulated data brokers).

The federal government is also disincentivized from passing a nationwide privacy law for the internet era because they’ve found that buying consumer data from data brokers is a wonderful way to avoid having to get a traditional warrant.

You could, on any random day, pluck any of a million mainstream news reports on consumer privacy from the newswire and not find a single one willing to make either of these causes clear to readers. Yes, getting everybody aligned on quality privacy legislation is difficult, but it’s not 30 straight years of inaction difficult. At some point, this reckless disregard for public welfare is a feature, not a bug.

All of that said, it’s evident that the public isn’t great when it comes to personal responsibility. Most of the users surveyed didn’t engage in basic protective measures like two-factor authentication or reliable, encrypted password managers:

“42% use multi-factor authentication, seen by experts as a good way to protect online accounts, and just over half (53%) use security questions to verify their identity. Only one in six (17%) said they use a password manager app or software that creates hard-to-break passwords, and 27% said they used biometric authentication such as facial recognition or fingerprint.”

In the absence of federal and state protection from reckless data monetization, consumers have to have their own backs, and it’s clear we’re not particularly good at that, either.

Filed Under: consumers, corruption, law, privacy, security, survey
